q: his life. Few of Michael Vick 's supporters have been as staunchly behind him as Reid. "He had a plan and he stuck to that, both on and off the field," Reid said. He knew certain things he wanted to get better at and he was open to the coaching on it, and he got himself back into shape.... So, he did a great job with the football part of it. "And then he spends a tremendous amount of time in the public, in particular on his days off... speaking and doing the best he can to right the wrong. You can never erase that, but you can sure help change others from falling into that same problem. A star in Atlanta for most of his six seasons as a Falcon after being selected first overall in the 2001 draft, Michael Vick missed 2007 and 2008 while incarcerated for 18 months in a federal prison.

big part of the profit picture for Chrysler going forward," says Mr Sergio Marchionne . The truck segment is under pressure, however, at least when it comes to the largest gas guzzlers. I think truck sales will be defined by the price of oil, the price of gasoline, GM's Mr Akerson says. Cynthia Jones says pickup trucks remain very popular "If there's a spike in the price of gasoline, I think it will affect the heavy end of the market."

anymore. "You know what? It's about the last thing on my mind right now," Ben Roethlisberger said when asked about how important it has been to rebuild his relationship with the city. It's about playing football, and that's what I try to do is play football games and win and just be me. The recipe for redemption in the NFL is quite simple: Behave yourself and win big. Ben Roethlisberger , like Ray Lewis and Michael Vick before him, has followed the redemption recipe to the hilt,

the season 4 semifinals and 16 contenders remained, including Louisiana native Lindsey Cardinale . Her version of the Idol staple impressed Randy, who responded simply with "wow, wow, wow," while Paula Abdul declared unapologetically, I'm not a fan of the song. Simon Cowell was less PC, of course, saying Lindsey Cardinale 's version was "the musical equivalent of Ryan Seacrest : you look the part, do everything right, and yet you're disappointed with the performance." not speak for the entire continent. "Ironically, my comment was unintentional," Donald Rumsfeld writes. "I had meant to say France and Germany represented "old NATO' not` old Europe'." In any event, the phrase` old Europe' entered the vernacular. The segments of Americans that preferred calling french fries` freedom fries" loved it, he writes. "The elites in Paris and Bonn who thought themselves the guardians of a sophisticated, new world order did not. All in all I was amused by the ruckus."

at a lower level so they can show some sort of improvement." National figures show just 15.6 per cent of pupils met the Baccalaureate threshold last summer. Conservative education minister Michael Gove said: In nearly every other developed country in the world children are assessed in a range of core academic subjects at 15 or 16. That is why the Coalition introduced the English Baccalaureate as a measure of performance. Schools will be asked to ensure at least 35 per cent of pupils gain five A* to C grade GCSEs including English and maths or face being closed down or turned into independent academies. Audio
